'''Brigitte Friang''' (1924–2011 [http://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/2011/03/08/97001-20110308FILWWW00726-deces-de-la-resistante-brigitte-friang.php]) was a French journalist and writer.
She was born in Paris in 1924 and immediately after leaving school in Paris in 1943 joined the French resistance.<ref name=Friang12>Friang (1958), 12–24.</ref> Working in the same group as Colonel [[F. F. E. Yeo-Thomas]], she was captured by the [[Gestapo]], shot while trying to escape, then taken to [[Fresnes Prison]] and tortured, before being deported to [[Ravensbrück concentration camp]].<ref name=Friang12/><ref name =fall138>Fall, 138.</ref>
After the war, she was liberated and returned to Paris where she worked for four years as a press aide to [[André Malraux]], before becoming a journalist.<ref name=Friang12/> In 1953, she was sent to [[French Indochina]] as a war correspondent.<ref name =fall138/><ref name=Friang25>Friang (1958), 25–27.</ref> There she undertook parachute training and was dropped, in the opening hours of [[Operation Castor]], into [[Điện Biên Province]], in the north-west corner of Vietnam.<ref name =fall138/><ref>Simpson, 29.</ref> She made several combat jumps including one with Lt Col Bigeard's 6th Colonial Paratroop Battalion at Tu-Le after which she accompanied the 6th on their retreat to French lines.<ref name=fall138/><ref name=windrow249>Windrow, 249</ref> She survived the war and returned to Paris where she worked as a writer and journalist until her retirement. On June 6, 1954 she appeared as a challenger on the TV panel show "What's My Line?" (the mystery guests for that episode were George Burns and Gracie Allen).
She died 6 March 2011 at the age of 87.
